newsitem.title: UK: Stability pact fines shouldn't be automatic - Clarke.
newsitem.headline: Stability pact fines shouldn't be automatic - Clarke.

text.p: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke said on Wednesday penalties imposed under a European Union stability pact should not be automatic and like the best deterrents would not necessarily be used.
"I have been against those who want automaticity in these penalties and rapid timetables," Clarke told Parliament.

"What we're negotiating is something that like the best deterrents would not be used but...reinforce the political will of a government to take the necessary action of its own to get back into conformity with its treaty commitments."

Clarke will attend an EU summit in Dublin later this week at which negotiations on a stability pact laying down potential fines for countries signed up for a single European currency which exceed their public debt targets, will move forward.

"I am determined to ensure there's nothing in the regulations of the stability pact that gives rise to any possibility...of legal consequences for the UK if we remain outside Economic and Monetary Union," Clarke said.
He said the pact's rules could not be so rigid nor the fines so harsh that every time a country exceeds its deficit target, it is fined so heavily that the situation is worsened.
"But whilst I am against inflexible rules and draconian penalties, we can't have a set of commitments so vague that they are more often broken than met."
"We intend to ensure that...it will be a system that a future British government can sign up to," he said.
